Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Exploiting synthetic GPCRs and mating factors as extracellular sensors for substrate-dependent assembly of complex cellulosomes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1263719/1263768/1263799
Chen/Robinson/Da Silva

The primary obstacle impeding the more widespread use of biomass for energy and chemical production is the absence of a low-cost technology for overcoming the recalcitrance of these materials. Cellulosomes are self-assembled multi-enzyme complexes found in many anaerobic microorganisms that are highly efficient for biomass depolymerization. The group of investigators have successfully developed a synthetic yeast consortium displaying a functional cellulosome for biofuel production. However, given the complexity of the different members involved in the consortium, engineering cell to cell coordination is the key in maintaining the required overall functionality. Their goal in this project is to design synthetic extracellular sensors that can be used to regulate the secretion of enzymes and adaptor scaffoldins involved in the assembly of the appropriate complex cellulosome structure in a substrate-dependent manner. The proposed research is scientifically significant because it will provide a general framework for the design of extracellular sensors that are important for other bioprocessing or biomedical applications. Moreover, graduate students participating in this research will gain an integrated perspective of the important interfaces and synergies connecting biochemistry, modern genetics, and process engineering to solve an important problem of our society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary obstacle impeding the more widespread use of biomass for energy and chemical production is the absence of a low-cost technology for overcoming the recalcitrance of these materials. It has been shown that the overall cost can be significantly reduced by using a one-step “consolidated” bioprocessing approach, where enzyme production, biomass hydrolysis, and sugar fermentation can be mediated in one bioreactor. Cellulosomes are self-assembled multi-enzyme complexes found in many anaerobic microorganisms that are highly efficient for biomass depolymerization. In the past, efforts have been focused on engineering a single species with multiple biochemical functions. In contrast, microorganisms naturally exist in synergistic communities, and this natural behavior has recently been exploited for biofuel production using a synthetic yeast consortium displaying a functional cellulosome. Given the complexity of the different members involved in the consortium, engineering cell to cell coordination is the key in maintaining the required overall functionality. Our strategy is to design synthetic extracellular sensors that can be used to regulate the secretion of enzymes and adaptor scaffoldins involved in the assembly of the appropriate complex cellulosome structure in response to external biomass compositions. Specifically, we propose to exploit the integral membrane G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that are involved in many intercellular communications in response to external stimuli. By designing synthetic mating factors that are responsive to extracellular nutrient conditions into regulated transcriptional outputs, sensing circuits with the ability to control gene expression over a wide range of cellulose or hemicellulose concentrations can be created.

 

We first demonstrated the feasibility of our strategy using the well-characterized α-factor, which activates the yeast mating pheromone response pathway upon binding onto its native receptor, Ste2p. This pathway is ideally suited to establish and validate our approach as it has been used as a model for all eukaryotic GPCR signaling pathway and engineered to perform a variety of synthetic functions with tunable behaviors. The yeast α-factor is a 13-amino acid peptide composed of three distinct domains: residues that initiate signaling in the N terminus, residues that mediate binding to Ste2p in the C-terminus, and a flexible loop region in the middle to orient the signaling and binding domains. Since mutations to either the N- or C- terminal region essentially abolish GPCR activation, these results indicate that both GPCR binding and activation are necessary for correct pathway signaling.  We hypothesized that split α-factor fragments composed of either the N- or C- terminal region that are incapable of activating the mating pathway can be created for intein-mediated functional reconstitution.

 

For effective intein ligation, an absolute requirement is a Cys residue at the +1 position after the C-extein. We designed a small library of synthetic α-factor analogues and screened them using a simple plate-based growth arrest assay based on the induction of cell cycle arrest in the G1 phase upon activating the mating pathway. By exploiting the easily observable growth arrest phenotype, we successfully identified two synthetic analogues that retain significant levels of biological activities. Using these two synthetic peptides, we designed inactive split fragments that can be reconstituted into active mating factors using either intein-based protein trans-splicing (PTS) or N-terminal cleavage (NTC) reactions. The ligated products not only retained the ability to trigger cell cycle arrest in a dosage-dependent manner, but also induced GFP expression from the pFus1 promoter in live yeast cells by more than 10-fold. These designs can potentially be tailored to any signaling peptides to be reconstituted, as the split inteins are promiscuous and both the peptides and the reactions are amendable to changes by directed evolution and other protein engineering tools, thereby offering a general strategy to implement synthetic control strategies in a large variety of applications.
